I often heard the unit-testing advice that you should test the things
you need confidence in, rather than anally testing everything in sight.
That advice has been expressed in a variety of ways, including "test
until you're bored", and it seems like sound advice to me. I'm curious,
however, as to how that advice squares with the notion of TDD.

Among other things, testing only the important bits means being
able to skip tests for setters and for getters. It also means not having

to write a test for the main loop that merely says "process every item
in the input collection", and get down to the nitty gritty of ensuring
that
the processing steps actually work.

In TDD, on the other hand, I understand that one is not supposed to
write a scrap of code until one has first written the failing test for
it.
This philosophy has two intriguing features:
   * 100% code coverage
       Because nothing gets written that doesn't have a test in the
first place.

   * Un-prejudiced design
      So you wind up creating the abstractions you really need, instead
      of the ones you first conceive of. The example of the multi-room
      game was illuminating in that respect. Instead of having a Room
      class, as one might expect, simple integers were all that was
      actually needed to represent a room. (Where did I read that?)

But writing tests first seems fundamentally incompatible with the notion

of testing only what you need to test. Or am I being anal about the
TDD idea, and in fact, "simple" code is written without first writing
tests?
(Or is there some other unifying idea I'm missing.)

As an aside, I'm curious to know if in TDD it is "kosher" to write
a failing test, examine the results and, if they look good, plug them
into the test. My thoughts so far are:
   1) It feels like cheating, because the test will then succeed even
        if my examination failed.

   2) I'm especially inclined to do it when the results are big, because

       it's so hard to manually generate the results I expect. But that
       means:
          a) It's even more likely that the visual examination will
overlook
              something.
          b) Taking advantage of the ability to cut and paste results
may
              incline me to make larger tests than I really should be
making.
